title: To Kill a Mockingbird
text: A novel by Harper Lee published in 1960. It was immediately successful, winning the Pulitzer Prize, and has become a classic of modern American literature.
A dystopian social science fiction novel and cautionary tale, written by the English writer George Orwell. It was published in 1949 and is set in a future totalitarian society.

title: Pride and Prejudice
text: A romantic novel of manners written by Jane Austen in 1813. The novel follows the character development of Elizabeth Bennet, the dynamic protagonist of the book.

title: The Great Gatsby
text: A 1925 novel by American writer F. Scott Fitzgerald. Set in the Jazz Age on Long Island, the novel depicts narrator Nick Carraway's interactions with mysterious millionaire Jay Gatsby.

title: Moby Dick
text: A novel by Herman Melville, published in 1851. The story follows Ishmael's maritime adventures and his quest for revenge against the white whale, Moby Dick.

title: War and Peace
text: A novel by Leo Tolstoy, first published from 1865 to 1869. It is regarded as one of Tolstoy's finest works and as one of the greatest novels ever written.

title: The Catcher in the Rye
text: A novel by J.D. Salinger, partly published in serial form in 1945–1946 and as a novel in 1951. It is a story about adolescent alienation and loss.

title: The Lord of the Rings
text: An epic high-fantasy novel written by English author and scholar J.R.R. Tolkien. The story began as a sequel to Tolkien's 1937 fantasy novel The Hobbit.

title: The Odyssey
text: An ancient Greek epic poem attributed to Homer. It is one of the oldest works of literature still read by contemporary audiences.

title: Crime and Punishment
text: A novel by the Russian author Fyodor Dostoevsky. It was first published in 1866. The novel is often cited as one of the supreme achievements in literature.

title: The Grapes of Wrath
text: A novel by John Steinbeck, published in 1939. The novel centers around the Joads, a poor family of tenant farmers displaced from their Oklahoma farm.

title: Jane Eyre
text: A novel by English writer Charlotte Brontë, published in 1847. It follows the experiences of Jane Eyre, her growth to adulthood, and her love for Mr. Rochester.

title: The Hobbit
text: A children's fantasy novel by J.R.R. Tolkien. It was published in 1937 and is a prequel to his famous work, The Lord of the Rings.

title: The Brothers Karamazov
text: A novel by Fyodor Dostoevsky, first published in 1880. It is a passionate philosophical novel that enters deeply into ethical debates of God, free will, and morality.

title: The Iliad
text: An ancient Greek epic poem attributed to Homer. The Iliad is set during the Trojan War, and it tells the story of the ten-year siege of the city of Troy.

title: Brave New World
text: A dystopian novel by English author Aldous Huxley, written in 1931 and published in 1932. Set in a futuristic World State, where citizens are environmentally engineered into an intelligence-based social hierarchy.

title: Les Misérables
text: A novel by Victor Hugo, first published in 1862, that tells the story of several characters, particularly the struggles of ex-convict Jean Valjean and his path to redemption.

title: Wuthering Heights
text: A novel by Emily Brontë, published in 1847 under her pseudonym Ellis Bell. It is her only novel and is now considered a classic of English literature.

title: Anna Karenina
text: A novel by the Russian author Leo Tolstoy, first published in 1877. It is regarded as one of Tolstoy's greatest works of literature.

title: Frankenstein
text: A novel by English author Mary Shelley, first published in 1818. The story of Victor Frankenstein, a young scientist who creates a sapient creature in a scientific experiment.
